posts.cooked:
We are using PathPlanner’s AutoBuilder.buildAutoChooser() to load .auto files into a chooser on shuffleboard. But we are seeing auto commands in the chooser which are no longer there in our source code. image 1115×954 95.4 KB

image 1115×954 95.4 KB

image 1115×954 95.4 KB

We have deleted home/lvuser/deploy/PathPlanner folder and redeployed our code and confirmed the autos being shown in the chooser are no longer there.

We think these non-existing autons have been saved through Preferences somehow. But how can we remove them? Is there a file on the Rio we can remove?

When I get on the robot again, maybe I’ll see if I open SmartDashboard instead if I see them in Preferences, like I found here in WPILIB docs: image 1018×664 85.1 KB

image 1018×664 85.1 KB

image 1018×664 85.1 KB

link_counts.title: Setting Robot Preferences — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
They are stored in deploy, but WPILib will not allow you to delete unused files there. ~ The only way ~ to clear the deploy folder at the moment is to reformat the RIO.

I stand corrected. You can also SSH as Root to clear it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.cooked: I believe you can delete files in the deploy folder using FTP. Don’t remember how though. Might be worth looking into.

posts.name: Jeremy Reed
posts.cooked:
You can also use PuTTY to SSH into the RIO as well and remove the files at /home/lvuser/deploy .

We ran into this a few times when editing path names and auto names.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
We just don’t automatically delete them, because we don’t like to remove files that the user may actually want.  PathPlanner is unusual in that it just enumerates over all files in the folder, rather than having a list in code.  As others have said, you can use FTP, SFTP, or SSH to delete files without a full reformat.

In addition, you can set up build.gradle to delete things for you on each deploy: Clearing the deploy directory on a roboRIO (running commands on the roboRIO)? - #10 by Thad_House

link_counts.title: Clearing the deploy directory on a roboRIO (running commands on the roboRIO)?
Robot Code Crashing with Pathplanner Autobuilder

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: This is incorrect.  Ssh in with the admin account. Then you can delete it.  The standard user accounts don’t have rights to do so.
